liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC has announced it will remove a number of official accounts from X, formerly known as Twitter. In an email to staff, ABC Managing Director David Anderson says a decision has been made "to further reduce our activity on X and focus our effort on the accounts that overwhelmingly provide the most value". The accounts which are NOT being removed are: ABC News (@abcnews) ABC Sport (@abcsport) ABC Chinese (@abcchinese) ABC Australia (@abcaustralia) The ABC closed X/Twitter accounts for Insiders, News Breakfast and ABC Politics in February, which Anderson says led to staff being exposed to less "toxic interactions". "We also found that closing individual program accounts helps limit the exposure of team members to the toxic interactions that unfortunately are becoming more prevalent on X," he says. "Concerningly, X has reduced its trust and safety teams. Additionally, it is introducing charges which make the platform increasingly costly to use."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ABC to remove some accounts from X (formerly Twitter)

children.content: (ABC)
The ABC has announced it will remove a number of official accounts from X, formerly known as Twitter.

In an email to staff, ABC Managing Director David Anderson says a decision has been made "to further reduce our activity on X and focus our effort on the accounts that overwhelmingly provide the most value".
The accounts which are NOT being removed are:
ABC News (@abcnews)
ABC Sport (@abcsport)
ABC Chinese (@abcchinese)
ABC Australia (@abcaustralia)
The ABC closed X/Twitter accounts for Insiders, News Breakfast and ABC Politics in February, which Anderson says led to staff being exposed to less "toxic interactions".
"We also found that closing individual program accounts helps limit the exposure of team members to the toxic interactions that unfortunately are becoming more prevalent on X," he says.
"Concerningly, X has reduced its trust and safety teams. Additionally, it is introducing charges which make the platform increasingly costly to use."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The public has crowned Jaq Grantford's Through the Window as the People's Choice winner of this year's Archibald exhibition at the Art Gallery of New South Wales. The Melbourne-based artist depicts Play School alumnus Noni Hazlehurst smiling and gazing through a rain-flecked window. More than 15,000 people cast a vote this year, and the win comes with $5,000 in prize money. Grantford says she is "blown away" to have received the award. "It's such an incredible honour to win the People's Choice award and a real testament to how beloved Noni is. "She is such a delightful person, and I love how people's faces light up when they mention her name. She has a real magic about her."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Portrait of Noni Hazlehurst wins Archibald Prize People's Choice award

children.content: The public has crowned Jaq Grantford's Through the Window as the People's Choice winner of this year's Archibald exhibition at the Art Gallery of New South Wales.
The Melbourne-based artist depicts Play School alumnus Noni Hazlehurst smiling and gazing through a rain-flecked window.
More than 15,000 people cast a vote this year, and the win comes with $5,000 in prize money.
Grantford says she is "blown away" to have received the award.
"It's such an incredible honour to win the People's Choice award and a real testament to how beloved Noni is.
"She is such a delightful person, and I love how people's faces light up when they mention her name. She has a real magic about her."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The driver of a bus that crashed after a wedding in the NSW Hunter Valley in June killing 10 people, has been charged with an additional 52 alleged offences, as more expert evidence is being sought. Brett Andrew Button was excused from appearing in Newcastle Local Court today as an amended charge sheet was tendered, containing a total of 63 alleged offences. An amended charge sheet tendered in court today included nine extra offences of negligent driving occasioning death, nine counts of dangerous driving occasioning grievous bodily harm and nine counts of negligent driving in occasioning grievous bodily harm. There are also 25 new charges of causing bodily harm by misconduct in charge of a motor vehicle. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hunter Valley wedding bus driver has more charges laid

featuredLink.title: Hunter Valley wedding bus driver excused from fronting court as 52 new charges laid

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank's boss says he expects more people to fall behind on their home loan repayments because of higher interest rates. As you've been hearing, Australia's biggest home lender made a record annual profit of $10.2 billion for 2023 thanks to more income from higher interest rates. Commonwealth Bank chief executive Matt Comyn says home loan arrears are near record lows but will rise as rate increases continue to be passed on.. "Across the economy, borrowers have only felt about two-thirds of the current cash rate increases," he told an analysts' briefing. "This is because repayments don't increase immediately and also due to the expiry of fixed rate loans." Mr Comyn says younger people are bearing the brunt of the rising cost of living. Here's more from my colleagues Michael Janda and Stephanie Chalmers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA boss warns mortgage arrears will rise

featuredLink.title: 'Downside risks building' for Australia's economy, warns CBA boss as bank makes record profit

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank's boss says he expects more people to fall behind on their home loan repayments because of higher interest rates.
As you've been hearing, Australia's biggest home lender made a record annual profit of $10.2 billion for 2023 thanks to more income from higher interest rates.
Commonwealth Bank chief executive Matt Comyn
says home loan arrears are near record lows but will rise as rate increases continue to be passed on..
"Across the economy, borrowers have only felt about two-thirds of the current cash rate increases," he told an analysts' briefing.
"This is because repayments don't increase immediately and also due to the expiry of fixed rate loans."
Mr Comyn says younger people are bearing the brunt of the rising cost of living.
Here's more from my colleagues Michael Janda and Stephanie Chalmers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Global credit ratings agency S & P Global Ratings says Australia looks like it may avoid a recession despite slowing global trade and higher interest rates to curb inflation. But it warns that a "soft landing is possible but not certain" for the economy as the Reserve Bank tries to bring inflation down to its target of between 2 to 3 per cent. "The key risk to a soft-landing scenario is that inflation is more sticky than generally expected and the Reserve Bank of Australia has to hike interest rates more strongly." "That could cause a sharper economic downturn and larger rise in unemployment." S & P Asia Pacific chief economist Louis Kuijs says the RBA's decision to pause official rates at 4.1 per cent shows it doesn't want to trigger a recession by lifting rates too much. The unemployment rate is near 50-year lows of 3.5 per cent and Mr Kuijs says the labour market strength has been driven by demand for workers in the services sector, which employs 80 per cent of workers, and makes up two-thirds of GDP. "The labour market tightness may also reflect some labour hoarding, as firms worry they may not easily find new employees if they let some go," he says. S & P expects the economy to expand by 1.4 per cent this year and unemployment to rise moderately. That's more optimistic than the RBA's forecast of 0.9 per cent. The global ratings agency says if a rise in the unemployment rate can be limited to around 1 percentage point, then the economic and financial fall out should remain "manageable."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Soft landing 'not certain' for Australian economy

children.content: Global credit ratings agency S
P Global Ratings says Australia looks like it may avoid a recession despite slowing global trade and higher interest rates to curb inflation.
But it warns that a
"soft landing is possible but not certain"
for the economy as the Reserve Bank tries to bring inflation down to its target of between 2 to 3 per cent.
"The key risk to a soft-landing scenario is that inflation is more sticky than generally expected and the Reserve Bank of Australia has to hike interest rates more strongly."
"That could cause a sharper economic downturn and larger rise in unemployment."
S
P Asia Pacific chief economist Louis Kuijs
says the RBA's decision to pause official rates at 4.1 per cent shows it doesn't want to trigger a recession by lifting rates too much.

The unemployment rate is near 50-year lows of 3.5 per cent and Mr Kuijs says the labour market strength has been driven by demand for workers in the services sector, which employs 80 per cent of workers, and makes up two-thirds of GDP.
"The labour market tightness may also reflect some labour
hoarding, as firms worry they may not easily find new employees if they let some go," he says.
S
P expects the economy to expand by 1.4 per cent this year and unemployment to rise moderately.
That's more optimistic than the RBA's forecast of 0.9 per cent.
The global ratings agency says if a rise in the unemployment rate can be limited to around 1 percentage point, then the economic and financial fall out should remain "manageable."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Suncorp reported a 69% jump in full-year profit, yet it's one of today's worst-performing stocks. By 12:45pm AEST, its share price was down 2.1% to $13.46. In its results announcement, the insurer warned of challenges posed by high inflation and the financial impact of adverse weather events (ie. natural disasters). Suncorp's lower-than-expected dividend also weighed on its share price. Australia's second-largest insurer announced a fully franked final dividend of 27 cents per share (which was lower than consensus estimate of 40 cents, and Citi's estimates of 39 cents). "The operating environment remains challenging," Suncorp said, forecasting an insurance gross written premium growth of around 10% in fiscal year 2024 (compared with a 10.8% growth seen in previous year for combined Australia and New Zealand units). "The dividend will likely disappoint some and the guidance, while largely as expected, suggests a relatively tough 1H24 with the lingering issues in motor inflation we expected," analysts at Citi wrote in a research note. Lower end of shareholder payout, higher costs ahead Suncorp's full-year dividend payout ratio was 60% of its cash earnings, at the lower end of its range of 60% to 80%. Analysts at Citi said they believed the ordinary payout reflects a significant drain on the capital of the company. Suncorp posted annual cash earnings of $1.25 billion, compared with $673 million a year earlier, helped by improved underlying margins and a significant turnaround in investment returns. Net gain from yields and investment markets was $724 million for the year, compared with a loss of $190 million in 2022, the company said in a statement. The insurer also flagged an increase in costs related to the $4.9 billion divestment of banking unit to ANZ Group to between $575 million and $600 million (up from $500 million) after the ACCC blocked the deal. - Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Suncorp shares fall on lower-than-expected dividend

children.content: Suncorp reported a 69% jump in full-year profit, yet it's one of today's worst-performing stocks.
By 12:45pm AEST, its share price was down 2.1% to $13.46.
In its results announcement, the insurer warned of challenges posed by high inflation and the financial impact of adverse weather events (ie. natural disasters).
Suncorp's lower-than-expected dividend also weighed on its share price.
Australia's second-largest insurer announced a fully franked final dividend of 27 cents per share (which was lower than consensus estimate of 40 cents, and Citi's estimates of 39 cents).

"The operating environment remains challenging," Suncorp said, forecasting an insurance gross written premium growth of around 10% in fiscal year 2024 (compared with a 10.8% growth seen in previous year for combined Australia and New Zealand units).

"The dividend will likely disappoint some and the guidance, while largely as expected, suggests a relatively tough 1H24 with the lingering issues in motor inflation we expected," analysts at Citi wrote in a research note.
Lower end of shareholder payout, higher costs ahead
Suncorp's full-year dividend payout ratio was 60% of its cash earnings, at the lower end of its range of 60% to 80%.
Analysts at Citi said they believed the ordinary payout reflects a significant drain on the capital of the company.
Suncorp posted annual cash earnings of $1.25 billion, compared with $673 million a year earlier, helped by improved underlying margins and a significant turnaround in investment returns.
Net gain from yields and investment markets was $724 million for the year, compared with a loss of $190 million in 2022, the company said in a statement.

The insurer also flagged an increase in costs related to the $4.9 billion divestment of banking unit to ANZ Group to between $575 million and $600 million (up from $500 million) after the ACCC blocked the deal.
- Reuters
